channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Whale-Watching Boat Sinks Off British Columbia Coast
item.description: At least five people were killed after a boat carrying more than two dozen tourists sank near Tofino, on Vancouver Island.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK
item.media:description: Rescuers parked on a dock in Tofino, British Columbia, after a whale-watching boat carrying 27 people sank offshore.

item.title: Tight Vote in Argentina Yields Presidential Runoff
item.description: Mauricio Macri, the mayor of Buenos Aires, began to edge past Daniel Scioli, the candidate endorsed by President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, according to partial results.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO and JONATHAN GILBERT
item.media:description: Voter lists in Buenos Aires on Sunday. Many voters want a break from President Kirchner's style.

item.title: European Leaders Look Again for a Unified Response to Migrant Crisis
item.description: The gathering was the fifth consecutive meeting of leaders focused on so far fruitless efforts to deal with Europe’s biggest refugee crisis since the end of World War II.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece at a meeting in Brussels on Sunday.

item.title: Facebook’s Internet for All Is a Tough Sell in India
item.description: Facebook’s rocky experience since it brought stripped-down Internet access to India shows that good intentions and technological savvy are not enough.
item.dc:creator: VINDU GOEL
item.media:credit: Asmita Parelkar for The New York Times
item.media:description: “The Reliance connection is very patchy,” said Shoaib Khan at his perfume and cellphone shop in Mumbai, India. “I would really have to sell the customer on it.”

item.title: Jimmy Morales Is Elected New President in Guatemala
item.description: Running on the slogan “Not corrupt, nor a thief,” Mr. Morales benefited from his image as a political outsider after an anticorruption movement brought down President Otto Pérez Molina.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN and NIC WIRTZ
item.media:description: Jimmy Morales, the comedian running for president, after he voted Sunday in Guatemala City.

item.title: The Offshore Game of Online Sports Betting
item.description: The story of Pinnacle Sports is a case study in how bookmaking sites, illegal in the United States, manage to operate on American soil.
item.dc:creator: JAMES GLANZ, AGUSTIN ARMENDARIZ and WALT BOGDANICH
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pinnacle Sports first established its headquarters on the second floor of the Holiday Beach Hotel and Casino in the Caribbean island nation of Curaçao.

item.title: Right-Wing Party Roars Back in Polish Elections
item.description: Law and Justice party won 39.1 percent of the vote on Sunday with a platform mixing calls for higher wages with appeals to traditional Catholic values, and Prime Minister Ewa Kopacz later conceded defeat.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN
item.media:description: Beata Szydlo, right, candidate for prime minister, and Jaroslaw Kaczynski, left, leader of the Law and Justice Party, celebrated with supporters in Warsaw after winning the Polish elections on Sunday.

item.title: Fraud Claims Delay Elections in Two Ukrainian Cities
item.description: Late Saturday, with just 12 hours before polls were to open, election officials said they had discovered printing flaws on the ballots and destroyed them.
item.dc:creator: ALISA SOPOVA
item.media:description: Members of an election commission inspected ballots Sunday in a printing firm in Mariupol. Flaws were said to be found.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Israel’s Irresponsible Arabs
item.description: Arab leaders must remember that their community has a stake in coexistence with the Jewish majority.
item.dc:creator: SHMUEL ROSNER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: South Africa’s Student Revolt
item.description: Extending access to higher education is not some socialist dream; it's a vital part of stabilizing the country.
item.dc:creator: NICKY FALKOF
item.media:description: Students marching at the University of the Witwatersrand in Johannesburg last week.

item.title: Venezuelan Prosecutor Says Opposition Leader’s Trial Was a Farce
item.description: In a video posted online, a prosecutor, Franklin Nieves, criticizes a trial in which he helped convict Leopoldo López, calling it a farce, and says he has left Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN and PATRICIA TORRES

item.title: Japan’s Struggling Economy Finds ‘Abenomics’ Is Not an Easy Fix
item.description: Nearly three years after Prime Minister Shinzo Abe took office, there are signs that growth is faltering again, despite Mr. Abe’s efforts to spur the economy.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE
item.media:description: A poster in Tokyo showing Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan.

item.title: Lugu Lake Journal: ‘Kingdom of Daughters’ in China Draws Tourists to Its Matrilineal Society
item.description: Fascination with the Mosuo, an ethnic minority where daughters are prized and marriage is not traditional, has brought tourism but also fears its practices could fade away.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Mosuo man fishing on the edge of Lugu Lake in Luoshui, China.

item.title: Opinion: With G.M.O. Policies, Europe Turns Against Science
item.description: An irrational phobia of genetically modified crops is causing real harm.
item.dc:creator: MARK LYNAS
item.media:description: A cornfield near Roquettes, France, after hundreds of activists uprooted genetically modified plants to replace them with organic ones in May 2014.

item.title: Catholic Paper on Family Is Hailed by All Sides, Raising Fears of Disputes
item.description: A document on family life that emerged from the synod did not erase disagreements on divorce and other issues and could widen the divisions further.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: Pope Francis after a Mass on Sunday observing the end of the synod.

item.title: Tony Blair Says Iraq War Helped Give Rise to ISIS
item.description: The former British prime minister was apologetic in an interview on CNN that comes as results of a public inquiry into the war are set to be revealed.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Indonesia to Decide on Joining Trans-Pacific Partnership
item.description: The United States-led trade pact is seen as a bulwark against Chinese influence in the region, even without Indonesia, Southeast Asia’s largest economy.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: The Indonesian president, Joko Widodo, answered questions last week from representatives of elementary school students, playing the role of young reporters, at the Presidential Palace in Jakarta.

item.title: Two Children Among Migrants Drowned Near Greek Island
item.description: Seven people were missing after an inflatable dinghy carrying dozens of migrants from Turkey hit rocks near the island of Lesbos, Greek authorities said.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.media:description: Firefighters carried the body of a child on the Greek island of Lesbos after a dinghy sank in choppy waters shortly before dawn on Sunday.

item.title: Russian Ships Near Data Cables Are Too Close for U.S. Comfort
item.description: The ultimate hack could involve severing the cables at their most remote locations and halt the communications on which the West has grown dependent.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Adm. Mark Ferguson said the intensity of Russian submarine patrols had risen by almost 50 percent over the last year.

item.title: Caught Between Protesters and Israel, Palestinian Security Forces Shift Tactics
item.description: Amid violent protests in the West Bank, a longtime security alliance with Israel may be redefined in the face of public anger and mistrust.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID and RAMI NAZZAL
item.media:description: Israeli security forces at a checkpoint near the West Bank town of Jenin. At one time, Palestinian security forces worked closely with their Israeli counterparts, but that coordination is shifting.
